The attendant glanced up as a hand slammed down onto the table, rattling the jar of ink and the quill within it. From the look on his face, the man was entirely unimpressed.
“Can I help you?”
The teen before him grinned, a toothy smile shot full of confidence and promising nothing but trouble.

Not one of these kids again.

“I’d like to be entered into the tournament please, if you would,” the kid said with the casual air of someone who expects everything to magically work out in their favor, somehow. He’d seen it all before, though. Some upstart wandered into the tent every year, expecting to be entered into the fights and win because they were Mommy’s special boy with an ego and a god complex.
The attendant glanced down at the scuffed iron sword tucked into the waist of the boy’s pants, skeptical. “Are you sure about that?”
“Absolutely, big man. Completely fuckin’ positive.”
The grin hadn’t faded. 

This kid has no idea what’s coming.

He squinted up at the teen. “You have a proper sword? A shield? Literally any gear? That toothpick you’ve got there won’t do much for you, I’ll be honest.”
There was an annoyed huff, followed by a rolling of eyes. “Yeah, yeah, I know it’s not fancy or anything, but I’ll be fine.” The boy reached down and patted the worn hilt lovingly. “She’s saved my ass plenty of times, don’t worry about it.”
The attendant sighed, reaching out to pluck the quill from the bottle, hovering over a chart of names. “Your funeral, I guess. Name?”
“Tommy Innit.”
There was a scratching of pen on paper, another name added to the growing list of participants. This kid would simply be one of many who got their ass beat in the arena. Wouldn’t be the first time.
With a final flourish, the teen’s name was registered. “Alright, rounds start tomorrow, at noon. Bracket system will be used, winner of the pair advances to the next round, you know the drill.” The attendant looked up at the boy who stared back at him, eyes filled with both excitement and a serious determination.
“Welcome to the Tournament of the Gods, Tommy Innit.”
 
———————
 
Tommy sauntered out of the tent, whistling merrily to himself. A grin split his cheeks, hands tucked into his fraying pockets as he made his way down the crowded street, dodging tourists, vendors, and the occasional small child with ease. 
He had done it. They had actually let him in. 

He was in the Tournament.

The crowd up ahead grew thicker, the flow of people slowing down to a crawl as different stands popped up from the streets, all sorts of fruits and baked goods stacked upon each other, bright banners and scarves hung and fluttering in the wind, ornate knives and swords shimmering in the noonday sun. Tommy meandered through the market, stopping at the occasional stand to admire a neat sword, or to chat with the nice lady who ran the fruit stand and always snuck him an apple or two. (He loved that lady.)
This time of year was always the busiest, the most lively the city ever was. It was also Tommy’s favorite. People flocked from all over the place to participate in the annual festival, and to witness the main attraction, the infamous “Tournament of the Gods”. 
The whole point of the celebration was to honor the deities who were believed to watch over the earth, bestowing hints of their powers and wisdom upon only the most worthy and righteous. The whole idea of the tournament first began as a way to provide the gods with a clear candidate for the blessing, offering up a victor at the end of many duels and trials. Over time, the seriousness of the tournament relaxed, and more people entered just for the sake of the challenge.
But there were still some who took the tournament seriously, training year round just for the chance to obtain the blessing of the gods. Personally, Tommy thought those people were insane and really needed to get a hobby. 
He, on the other hand, had entered because he was bored and had nothing better to do with his time. Plus, it’d be funny.

Not that anyone else would get the joke but him, but still. The opportunity was too good to pass up.

Seventeen was the cutoff for the competition. Sure, some kids snuck in every year, squeezing by with a bit of early height to them, but no one younger than 20 or something had made it to the finals, much less won the thing. 
Tommy was going to be the first. That was just a fact.
After a little more perusing, Tommy left the crowded market square, making his way down toward the older part of the city, ancient buildings built of stone and brick, friendly fronts sagging with age and generations of memories. 
He’d go back to the market that night for the ceremony and dance at sundown that celebrated the official opening of the festival. The music was always wonderful, and he couldn’t wait to retreat to his favorite rooftop and let the melodies wash over him, warming him even as the sun dipped below the horizon. It was tradition, after all.
Humming to himself, Tommy wandered down the worn cobble street. The size of the crowd was much thinner in this area, the atmosphere a more somber one, full of a quiet sort of reverence and respect as opposed to the energetic fervor of the marketplace. This attitude, while the polar opposite of the personality that was one Tommy Innit, was a familiar and comforting one.
Up ahead, the buildings fell away, singling out a lone structure, made of carefully crafted pillars of quartz and granite, the grounds well kept. The city temple, dedicated to the gods. Traffic to the temple was heavier than usual, but that was to be expected this time of year.
After all, it was a festival for the gods. Duh.
Tommy skipped up the steps, perfectly at home among the airy ceilings and polished stone floors. People flocked to a raised dais at the center of the room, three quartz statues standing proud upon it. An open skylight in the roof bathed the sculptures in sunlight, highlighting the dramatic curves and features of the deities depicted. 
Tommy’s steps slowed, coming to a halt behind a group of religious visitors, some lost in prayer or simply just in awe of the sight before them. 
The Blood God, the Siren, and the Angel of Death all stared back with blank expressions, looking down upon the mortals with empty stone eyes. 
Majestic, right?
Snickering to himself, Tommy stepped forward into the line of sight of the statues before promptly flicking them all off. 
Beside him, he heard a horrified gasp, and Tommy turned, raising an eyebrow at the scandalized look that a woman was giving him.
“You alright, miss?” he asked, choking back another laugh at the look on her face. Priceless.
“Do you have any idea what you’ve done?” she breathed, glancing up at the stern faces of the gods before them. “You’ve just insulted the deities in their temple, right on the opening night of the celebrations! How do you think they’re going to react?”
Tommy rolled his eyes, stuffing his hands back in his pockets. “I’m pretty sure they don’t mind, not the exactly first time I’ve done shit like that.”
The woman’s eyes widened even more.
Tommy smirked. “Won’t be the last time, either. Gotta keep up good ‘abits, right?”
She took a step back, shaking her head. “May the gods have mercy on you, child. You’ll need it.”
“I really don’t, but thanks anyway.”
The woman scurried away to another corner of the temple, casting a fearful glance over her shoulder as she went.

Never fails to freak someone out. Classic.

Tommy grinned up at the statues, perfectly at ease. No lightning bolts rained down from the sky, no heart attack made him drop down dead at the feet of the believers around him. This was as to be expected, considering greeting the statues with a curse or quick toss of the middle finger had been his routine for years now.
Some god-fearing believer, steadfast in their concern over the power of the gods always decided to question his sanity. The record number of requests for mercy on his soul in one day was somewhere around 11. He was still trying to beat that record, but hadn’t come close yet.
All of this wasn’t to say that Tommy wasn’t a believer in gods and immortal beings. Far from it. In fact, out of everyone in this room, in this city, hell- maybe in the nation– Tommy could easily be called the most faithful person out there. It’s just that he didn’t buy into the whole “treat them with utter respect because otherwise fiery hell will rain down upon you and curse your bloodline for the next 1000 years to always have bad luck” shit. 
He knew better.
Pleased with his personal choice of greeting, Tommy separated from the small crowd grouped around the statues, slipping away into an emptier part of the temple. Torches lit up the walls where the sunlight from the central chamber didn’t quite reach, combating what would otherwise be a persistent sense of abandonment. Tommy casually passed pillars and carvings depicting the history of the city and the gods' influence, heading for the back of the temple. 
Up ahead, the torch-lit gloom cleared, revealing a small window cut into the walls of the temple, the glass long gone and letting in a warm breeze. Across from it was a forgotten alcove, filled with a messy pile of blankets, the walls hung with various mementos, trinkets precariously balanced upon a shelf made of two carved quartz wings.

Home.

Without hesitation, Tommy flopped face first into the mound of blankets, enjoying the familiar comfort after a long day of standing in line in front of that stupid tent. Gods, the other people there had been so fucking annoying, telling him to go home and find his mommy.
Well he didn’t have one, thank you very much. Take that, idiots.
Groaning, Tommy rolled over, staring at the ceiling for a moment. He soaked up the peace, letting the events of the morning wash over him.
Once satisfied with his brief moment of contemplation, Tommy sat up, shouting “‘Ey bitches, I’m back!”
For a moment, nothing happened.
And then the gentle breeze coming through his little window picked up, rushing into the corridor and swirling about. The sunlight grew brighter, the space swelling with light for a split second, rising in a crescendo along with the wind for a moment before dying back down again. The air stilled, light dimming, and the corridor was once again restored to its previous state of emptiness.
A hand reached out and ruffled Tommy’s hair.
He smiled, leaning into the feeling of fingers gently carding through the curly mess. “Fucking took you long enough.”
There was an annoyed huff, and the hand left his hair, much to his dismay. “I was busy. Answering prayers, being a benevolent and all powerful being, that sort of thing.”
Tommy leaned back, eyebrow raised at the being in front of him. “Normally you show up the instant I offer my greeting. I was waiting for you to appear an’ cause a scene. Imagine my disappointment, Wil.”
Wilbur sighed, settling himself down on the ground in front of Tommy. “Yeah, yeah gremlin. No need to get all worked up about it. I’ll help you terrorize the public during the ceremony tonight, deal?”
“Sounds great, but ’m not sure Mr. Righteous Angel is gonna be cool with that, Big Dubs. Remember what happened last time you accidentally revealed yourself to the general public?”
Wilbur rolled his eyes, leaning back on the palms of his hands. “It was just a little increase in traffic at the temple, Tommy. Not really a big deal-”
“You started a religious revival,” he deadpanned. “There were suddenly prophets claiming the world was ending every other hour. It was awful.”
He remembered that disaster vividly, despite the years between then and now. People screaming on the streets, flooding the temple with worried visits and desperate prayers. The chaos made it hard to sleep and people kept getting in his way, begging him to save himself from the end of the world. In summary, awful.
Wilbur waved him off. “As if that doesn’t happen like once a decade or so, come on.”
Tommy leveled him with an unimpressed look.
“Fine, moving on.” Wil's expression shifted to one of excitement, a mischievous grin taking over his face. He leaned in. “Did they let you in? Are you in the tournament?”
Tommy scoffed. “Of fuckin’ course I am!” He puffed out his chest, posing. “They wouldn’t refuse Big Man Innit the opportunity to gain the favor of the gods, not with how absolutely poggers and worthy I am!”
They both grinned, knowing damn well Tommy didn’t need a competition of all things to gain the attention of higher powers.
Wilbur snickered. “Yeah, right. I’m sure that’s how it went.“
Tommy’s pose faltered, triumphant look deflating. “That guy acted like a right bastard,” he muttered angrily. “Judged my sword ’n everything. Do you know how rude that is? How offensive? I am wounded, Wil. Gutted. Destroyed. There will be no recovering from this-“
Wilbur reached forward and flicked him on the forehead, laughing at the scandalized expression he got in response. “I’m sure your pride will be fine. In all my centuries, I’ve never met someone with an ego half as large as yours. You’ll recover.”
“I’m taking that as a compliment.”
“You do that.”
Wilbur stood and stretched, golden robes shifting around him, catching the light. “I’ll inform Techno of the news. I’m sure he’ll actually bother to watch the tournament this year now that there’s someone actually interesting to cheer for.”
“Awe, so you do care!”
Wilbur laughed, reaching out to ruffle his hair once more. “Of course I do, Toms. You’re our favorite mortal, it’s always been that way-“
“You’re doing the clingy god shit again.”
Wilbur just smiled at him. “I’ll see you on the rooftop tonight, okay?”
“Sounds great, Big Man. See you there.”
With a twist of the light and warping of air, the Siren was gone once again.
Tommy leaned back into his little alcove, watching the sky through the window. He grinned.
Tomorrow, he would be competing in the Tournament of the Gods, fighting tooth and nail for a chance at victory. For a chance to win the favor of the gods.

Music drifted up to the rooftops, from jukeboxes and people playing on their well-loved instruments, carried by a damp breeze that signaled the night’s beginning. The sun had set, leaving buildings to wait in darkness, their windows cold, rooms empty. Instead, the streets glowed with the golden light of lamps and torches. Brazers of flame washed the faces of laughing people bronze as they clapped along to the music or danced down the street, hand in hand. Children ran through the crowd, their shrieks trailing behind them like the colorful ribbons clutched in their fists, mimicking the banners that wove between rooftops, gently swaying in the wind.
Upon one of these roofs sat Tommy. His legs dangled over the busy main square, kicking absentmindedly as he looked out over the maze of streets glowing under the dark sky like Ariadne’s string through the labyrinth. To an outsider, the sight might be lonely: a kid sitting by himself in the dark, stuck above everyone else and alone. 
But Tommy wasn’t alone. He was just waiting.
He sighed, letting his arms go slack and flopping back onto the roof, staring up at the stars above him. They were taking fucking forever.
“Fuckin’ gods can teleport ’n shit and yet they’re always late- can’t have anything around here,” he grumbled, tracing the constellations with lazy fingers. “Next thing you know I’ll be dying or something and they’ll show up late for that, too-“
“Who’s dying?”
Tommy jumped in surprise, turning his head to glare at the sandals next to his face. “Me, now that you’ve given me a fuckin’ heart attack, idiot.”
There was a chuckle, followed by the quiet whisper of green robes as the Angel of Death sat down beside him, giving him a kindly pat on head in apology. “Sorry mate, forgot you can’t tell I’m coming when I use the shadows to travel.”
Tommy sat up, grumbling. “That’s because you’re always with Wil and he’s obnoxiously obvious with his flashy entrances.”
Phil laughed again. “Right you are.”
At that moment, the stars grew brighter, flaring in the sky as the fires below them twisted into something else entirely.
“Speak of the devil,” Phil said, smiling.
The alien light died down, and Wilbur appeared on the roof behind them, dusting off his golden robes.
Tommy didn’t turn around, gaze fixed on the city laid out before him. “You’re late, bitch.”
Wilbur huffed. “I’m not that late, it’s like two minutes or something-“
“One hour and twenty three minutes past sunset. That’s not two minutes, dickhead.”
The god sighed, coming over to sit beside him and drape an arm around Tommy’s shoulder, pulling him close despite half-hearted protests. Wilbur set his chin on top of Tommy’s head, ignoring the muttered curses he got in response. “To us, that’s practically nothing, child. Leave me be.”
Tommy tried to squirm his way out of Wilbur’s grip before quickly giving in, due to years of experience knowing that if he tried to escape, Wilbur would just charm him back into his arms again anyways. Stupid gods and their stupid godly powers.
(And no, he did not enjoy the hug. Absolutely not. Not at all. Shut up.)
“I’m never gonna leave you be,” he muttered. “‘M a big man who causes problems on purpose an’ you guys are never getting rid of me. Deal with it.”
Wilbur and Phil both chuckled at that, much to his offense. “We wouldn’t have it any other way, Toms,” Phil said kindly, smiling softly at him. “We’ll always want you around.”
Tommy leaned back into Wilbur, ignoring the stupid little coo the god always gave whenever he relented to the forced affection. “At least I’m not immortal,” he grumbled. “Could you imagine having to put up with you three bastards for eternity?” He scrunched up his face, tongue sticking out. “Yuck.”
The temperature on the roof dropped a degree or two, the way it always did when Tommy brought up the fact that he was actually in fact, a human, and liked it that way, thank you very much. Wilbur’s grip on him tightened ever so slightly. Tommy rolled his eyes. 

Possessive bastards, the lot of them.

“Speaking of,” he sat up, pushing away from Wilbur, who whined at the loss of child in his arms. “Unless I’m ‘allucinating, I’m only counting two of you. Where’s Techno at?”
Phil shrugged. “Not sure, haven’t seen him in a while. He’s probably off somewhere watching the drunk mortals fight in alleys and critiquing their form or something.”
Tommy nodded knowingly. “Sounds like him.”
Wilbur leaned forward, peering over the edge of the rooftop to watch the celebration taking place down below. “Why do you need him anyways? We can cause enough problems on our own to be entertaining- all I have to do is appear in the middle of that crowd over there-“
“Wil, no-“
Tommy crossed his arms, watching with a hidden smile as Phil pulled Wilbur away from the edge, giving him the “don’t start another episode of mass hysteria just for your own personal entertainment or I swear to myself I will punt you into the cosmos” look. 
Tommy hummed, looking out over the city. “You sure he’s not gonna come?”
Wilbur waved a hand. “Techno is a boring bitch, of course he wouldn’t-“
“Techno is what now?”
Tommy glanced behind him, grinning at the sight of the Blood God, pink hair flowing and arms crossed, one brow raised in a challenge. To anyone else, it would probably be intimidating, even frightening. Tommy was just happy to see him. 
Tommy cheered. “Blade! You’re here!” He turned to Wilbur, grin turning into a smirk. “Go make an appearance Wil, it seems the world is actually ending.”
A hand smacked the back of his head and he laughed, ducking away. “Very funny, kid. I’m cryin’ myself laughing.”
“Thank you, I try.”
Techno settled himself down next to them. “And for the record,” he said, turning to Wilbur with a smug look on his face. “I wasn’t skippin’ out cause I’m a loser, I was gettin’ these.” He reached into his scarlet robes and pulled out a paper bag, one that Tommy recognized instantly.
His eyes lit up, hand immediately grabbing for it. “I demand them this instant. Surrender the goods, big man.”
Techno grinned, passing the bag over. Tommy practically tore it open, grinning in delight at the contents. He stuck a hand in, pulling out a slice of “golden apple”. They were an imitation of the real thing, the specially made apples with magic imbued in them, used in battle for healing purposes. These ones were a street food made during the festival this time of year, coated in butterscotch candy and drizzled with a golden syrup.

Curiosity and confusion got the better of him, and Tommy pried open an eye, pulling his face out of Wilbur’s chest. Everyone swam into focus, the faces of all three peering down at him, a precarious mixture of relief, worry, and unbridled joy all at once.
“‘The fuck are you all lookin’ at?” He croaked, squinting up at them. “You never seen a dead person before?”
The somewhat pleasant mood dampened instantly, and both holds on him tightened, protective as ever. Techno’s gaze darkened, and Wilbur scowled. Something akin to grief flashed in Dream’s eyes, hurt written all over his face.
Tommy cringed internally at the reaction. A bit too soon for jokes, I guess.
“My bad,” he mumbled, pushing against Wilbur to sit up, the god helping him along, “Forgot comedy in a crisis situation isn’t always appreciated in this house. Fuckin’ nightmare, this place is.”
Somebody huffed out a faint laugh, and Tommy smiled, leaning back into Wilbur, who happily took the weight. “So what, you’ve all just been sitting around, waiting for me to wake up like total creeps?”
Dream shrugged, the hand not holding his reaching up to fiddle with the strings on that ugly hoodie of his. One that was miraculously free of blood, now. Probably Wil’s doing. “Pretty much.”
“Took you long enough to wake up,” Wilbur complained, snaking an arm around his middle, chin dropping over his shoulder. “You little prick.”
Despite the faux annoyance in his voice, Tommy could easily pick out the left over anxiety in it, proving the fact that some part of Wilbur had probably been waiting for him to not wake up at all. 
Considering he had fucking died, (he was still trying to wrap his head around that bit, honestly) Tommy really couldn’t blame the god.
He patted Wilbur’s arm reassuringly, laughing. “Don’t worry, Big Dubs, I’m good. Wonderful, actually. Never felt better rested, honestly-“
“You died, Tommy,” Techno cut in, voice flat. “Stop pretending that we weren’t worried for good reason.”
The rambles died on Tommy’s tongue, smile slipping away.
Oh. They were actually being serious about all this.
Alright.
“I second that,” Dream said, and Tommy’s gaze flicked over to his, locking eyes with him. The other tried to smile at him, but it was a weak, wobbly thing. “Kid, you-“ Dream choked a bit in the words, and Tommy watched wide-eyed as his friend suddenly teared up. “You died in my arms, Tommy. You know that you- that I- I had to hold you as you-“ He shook his head, looking away, gaze unfocused as he stared at something far beyond the polished stone of the temple.
This time, Tommy was the one to do the hand squeezing.
“I know you just woke up and everything,” his friend whispered, “But please don’t brush it all off already, not when it’s us. Not when we care about you this much.” Dream looked back, giving him a watery smile. “It’s okay to not be okay, you know?”
Tommy stared at him, then glanced over at Techno, at Wilbur. They all wore similar expressions, ones full of hastily mended heartbreak and a shit ton of love that Tommy didn’t really know what to do with. 
He felt himself take a shaky breath, not entirely sure why he felt unsteady all of a sudden. “Okay,” he murmured, looking back at Dream, who shot him a grateful smile that was quickly returned.
The whole dying thing hadn’t really processed yet. Maybe it would hit him in a couple hours, maybe a week from now. Maybe it never would. 
Even so, Tommy knew-
They’d be there for him when it did.
And that was enough.
“On a lighter note,” Techno began, cutting through the lingering heaviness in the air. “You know that loser at the tournament I was gonna tell you about?”
Tommy blinked, still trying to absorb the last few moments, but nodded anyway. He wasn’t sure where this was going.
Techno huffed out a laugh. “Turns out, it was this guy all along.” He jabbed a thumb in Dream’s direction, grinning. “Idiot didn’t even realize we were all rootin’ for you.”
“What?” Tommy asked, confused.
“Okay, first of all,” Dream interrupted, pointing an accusatory finger in Techno’s direction. “I resent that. Secondly, you’re a god, dude. If anything, you and Wilbur here should’ve figured it out, not me.”
Techno shrugged, crossing his arms. “Still a loser though.”
“I’m confused,” Tommy piped up, watching the two snark back and forth. “What the fuck are you talking about? How the hell did you all meet each other? What am I missing here?”
Behind him, Wil chuckled quietly. “These two idiots,” he said, amused, “Sat next to each other in the stands for the entire tournament and didn’t realize they were both cheering for you until about an hour ago.”
“Yeah, well, neither did you until now, Wilbur,” Techno defended.
“Oh no,” Wilbur said, voice smug. He leaned back against the statues behind them, taking Tommy with him, pressing their heads together. “I realized after Tommy pointed him out after the first round,” he shrugged, nonchalant, “I knew they were friends, just not how close.”
Techno and Dream gaped at him, betrayal written all over their faces.
“So you knew I was Tommy’s friend and still insulted my hoodie?” Dream complained, offended. “What the fuck, man?”
Tommy snickered at the looks on their faces, and he could feel Wil’s smile widen. 
“What can I say,” the god said with another shrug, “It’s a fucking horrendous color.”
“Told you,” Tommy sang, snickering. 
Dream pouted, but it was half-hearted, a twinkle to his eye. “Fine then,” he snapped jokingly, pulling his arms through the sleeves. “If you love it so much-“
“What are you-“
“Then you wear it,” Dream finished, yanking it over his head with an evil grin. Before Tommy could react, he was hit in the face with an eye-searing bundle of neon green.
Wilbur and Techno snickered as Tommy floundered, cursing as he pulled the thing off his face. “Are you fuckin’ serious?” He asked, and there was a genuine sincerity to the question.
“Dead,” Dream replied, deadpan.
Tommy pulled away from Wil, slipping the hoodie over his head, grumbling. “So he can make death jokes but I can’t? Fuckin’ unbelievable-“
This time, there was laughter.
Tommy popped his head out of the fabric and smiled, leaning back again as Wilbur shook with giggles behind him.
There would be a lot of shit to figure out- that was for sure. Coming to terms with his own death, dealing with the general public (that was going to be hell, he just knew), letting both sides of his strange family get used to each other.
(Though to be honest, he wasn’t really worried about that last one.)
But for now, he was breathing. His heart beat in his chest, protected by something warm and golden brought by the laughter of those he cared about the most.
Things would be okay.

A few days later, Tommy stood alone in the temple’s central chamber. The ever-familiar statues loomed above him, and he rocked back on his heels, paying no mind to the quill in his hand, slowly dripping ink onto the floor. He squinted, calculating.
If he climbed the statues just the right way, he’d be able to reach Wilbur’s cheek with the tip of the quill pen. The current plan was to draw a massive dick, but who knows. Maybe he’d get more creative once he was up there.
He snickered to himself, the sound echoing throughout the eerily empty room. Tommy had lived in his little alcove for years, and never once had the temple been this quiet- this empty.
It was rather nice, actually. Peaceful, easy to get around, and no one to stop some mild vandalism. You know, the important stuff.
Ever since the Tournament, things had been... different, to say the least. The gods and Dream were a pleasant constant, always checking up on him, spending time with him, the two sides of his life slowly coming together into one beautiful, chaotic whole. But everyone else in the city, well- they weren’t so casual about the whole thing.
Tommy hadn’t left the temple hardly at all, in the few days that it’s been since the Tournament. People were just too weird about it. They cast him all sorts of looks: awe, fear, bitterness or jealousy. The whole city was in a minor uproar, a near mirror image of the incident with Wilbur a few years back. Except this time, there was one major difference.
The Temple remained empty.
Tommy wasn’t sure if it was out of fear, out of respect for the fact that some people began to pick up on just how much time he spent there, or if Wil and Techno had done something to keep unwanted people out. He didn’t really care the reason- the lack of swarming people meant that the city temple became Tommy’s sanctuary, a respite from everything and everyone as he adjusted from being unknown to unforgettable.
Dream said he’d learn how to deal with it all, the fame and the attention. Tommy believed his friend, but some part of him still wished things would just hurry up and quiet down already. 
He set one foot on the marble dais and prepared to climb.
“...Tommy?” A voice called from behind, soft and hesitant.
He startled, dropping the quill and spattering ink all over the floor. Whoops. Tommy glanced over his shoulder, curious as to who the hell had finally bothered to come in here.
Quinn.

Really should’ve expected that one sooner or later.

“Hey Big Man,” Tommy replied, smiling, “What brings you here?”
Quinn stepped further into the room, looking around nervously, as if he felt out of place. “I was looking for you,” he said quietly, coming over to Tommy’s side, looking at him with an unfamiliar expression on his face. “I saw what happened through the gate- well, most of it at least,” he cringed, expression turning sorrowful. “I just- I wanted to make sure you were actually okay. That the whole... miracle, or whatever wasn’t just some crazy dream. People told me to come here,” Quinn smiled weakly over at him. “And here you are.”
“‘Here I am,” Tommy agreed, stuffing his hands into the pocket of the hoodie he wore. “An’ I’ve never been better, really.”
“Is that so?” Quinn asked, a hint of familiar amusement in his voice. “And how’s that?”
Tommy grinned. “Well I’m fucking famous now, aren’t I? Kicked that bastard’s ass, won the tournament, and even got a sick scar out of it to boot.” He pulled one hand from his pocket, lifting the hem of his shirt to expose the silvery, rope-like scar running across his stomach, its twin on his back.
Quinn glanced at it for a moment, and Tommy let his shirt drop. “So they really had to heal you, huh,” he observed quietly, looking up at the statues in front of them.
Tommy just shrugged, not feeling like making a big deal out of details right now. “Something like that.”
“I’m glad you’re okay,” Quinn said quietly, not looking Tommy’s way. “I kept feeling like- I don’t know,” he huffed, frustrated. “Like I should’ve done more, somehow.”
Tommy shrugged again. “Not your fault, Q. There was nothing you could’ve done.”
A little bit of the tension fell from Quinn’s shoulders, and he ran a hand through his hair. “I guess,” he muttered.
Silence fell between the two of them- not quite awkward, but more so the silence of two people who weren’t quite sure how to fit into the other’s life anymore, now that things weren’t quite so simple. They stood there, quietly staring at the statues in front of them, slowly trying to warm back up to one another.
“So did they like- bless you, or anything?” Quinn asked timidly, glancing at him out of the corner of his eye, almost as if he was a bit scared to pry. “For winning?”
Tommy snickered, raising an eyebrow. “What, you mean beside the whole,” he gestured at his front, “Resurrection shit?”
“Yeah,” Quinn agreed, looking a little awkward, but laughing nonetheless. “Besides that.”
Tommy hummed, tilting his head. “Nope. It’s totally cool though- I just like being alive. That’s fuckin’ good enough for me.”
“Fair enough.” His former partner craned his neck, looking up at the regal, stoic statues before him. A faint smile appeared on Quinn’s face, and he shook his head, laughing to himself. “Don’t know why I’m surprised. Only you would brush off the idea of being blessed by the gods, Tommy.”
“Well,” Tommy began slowly, following Quinn’s gaze, taking in the familiar faces before him, the ones that lacked the warmth and love he knew so well. A silent, faded reminder of what he truly had. Of how lucky he really was. Absent-mindedly, his fingers twisted around the strings of the neon hoodie he wore.
Tommy stared up at the statues.
They stared back.
He smiled.
“I think I’m plenty blessed as it is, Big Man.”
